name: Romanico
description: Romanesque art, known for its solid and massive structures, rounded arches, and symbolic religious iconography, focused on depicting biblical narratives.

name: Gotico
description: Gothic art is characterized by its use of pointed arches, ribbed vaults, and flying buttresses, with an emphasis on verticality and light-filled structures, especially in cathedrals.

name: Umanesimo
description: Humanism, an intellectual movement that inspired art with a focus on the human form, classical antiquity, and the exploration of individualism, laying the groundwork for the Renaissance.

name: Rinascimento
description: Renaissance art emphasized realism, proportion, and perspective, with artists striving for idealized beauty and balance, heavily influenced by classical Greco-Roman art.

name: Barocco
description: Baroque art is known for its dramatic use of light and shadow, emotional intensity, and elaborate ornamentation, often used to evoke awe and convey power, particularly in religious contexts.

name: Rococo
description: Rococo is an ornate style marked by playful, light, and decorative elements, often with themes of love and nature, emphasizing asymmetry and elaborate detail.

name: Neoclassicismo
description: Neoclassicism drew inspiration from the simplicity and symmetry of ancient Greek and Roman art, reflecting Enlightenment ideals and emphasizing rationality, order, and classical restraint.

name: Romanticismo
description: Romanticism focused on individual emotion, nature, and imagination, often presenting themes of heroism, exoticism, and the sublime as a reaction against industrialization and neoclassicism.

name: Realismo
description: Realism depicted everyday life and ordinary people with accuracy and detail, rejecting idealization and focusing on the unvarnished truth of social conditions and labor.

name: Impressionismo
description: Impressionism captured the effects of light and color in everyday scenes, often with visible brushstrokes and emphasis on atmosphere, movement, and fleeting moments.

name: Post-Impressionismo
description: Post-Impressionism extended the ideas of Impressionism but emphasized symbolic content, formal structure, and expressive color, leading to diverse styles such as pointillism and synthetism.

name: Giapposismo
description: Japonisme refers to the influence of Japanese art on Western artists, characterized by asymmetry, flat planes of color, and decorative, simplified compositions.

name: Art Nouveau
description: Art Nouveau, marked by flowing lines, organic forms, and intricate patterns, often combined craftsmanship with industrial materials, inspired by natural motifs.

name: Fauvismo
description: Fauvism used bold, non-naturalistic colors and simple forms to express emotion, with an emphasis on painterly qualities over realistic representation.

name: Cubismo
description: Cubism broke down objects into geometric shapes and multiple perspectives within a single plane, emphasizing abstraction and the flatness of the canvas.

name: Futurismo
description: Futurism celebrated speed, technology, and modernity, with dynamic compositions representing movement and the power of industrial society.

name: Espressionismo
description: Expressionism sought to convey subjective emotions and responses, often through distorted forms, intense colors, and loose brushwork to evoke mood.

name: Surrealismo
description: Surrealism explored the unconscious mind through dreamlike and fantastical scenes, combining strange juxtapositions and illogical imagery to challenge reality.

name: Astrattismo
description: Abstract art moved away from representation to focus on colors, shapes, and forms to evoke ideas or emotions, existing independently from the physical world.
